author: Sylvia Pennington
title: Can an image overhaul get golf back on course?
text:
Is the sun about to set on golf as a sport for corporates and business types? iStock by Sylvia Pennington It's historically been the sport of choice for business heavyweights but the past decade has seen golf lose ground to more adrenalised alternatives such as cycling, triathlons and Tough Mudder-style endurance events.
Golfing great Greg Norman believes sexing the game up a tad – as other ultra-conservative sports such as cricket and lawn bowls have done – may be what's needed to get more young people to pick up the clubs.
He's called for a relaxed dress code, shorter games – 12 holes instead of the traditional 18 – and music on the course to help reverse the membership decline that has placed 50 per cent of Australian golf clubs under financial duress.
But would dispensing with the polo shirt and long socks rule and blasting Avicii through the golf cart speakers be enough to lure the latest crop of young executives onto the course more often?
Is the sun about to set on golf as a sport for corporates and business types? iStock Or is schmoozing and boozing your way to the nineteenth hole destined to become an activity only indulged in by bizzoids of a certain age?
A dying sport? Telecoms executive Jamie Romanin, 38, thinks so. A frequent player at business golf days and on weekends in younger years, he's now a passionate cyclist and triathlon competitor with no desire to pull out the clubs more than once or twice a year.
"The days of golf are dying off," Romanin says.
 "Similar to the day of the long lunch … it died off some time ago. Everyone's time poor, we live frenzied lives … we're squeezing much more into our lives. I don't know many executives who can take five hours out for a game of golf."
Cycling, which blends business and pleasure more time efficiently, has become the favoured alternative, both for his demographic and a growing number of executives in their 40s and 50s.
Romanin believes the networking opportunities are just as good – both puffing up hills and enjoying après-ride lattes in the coffee shop – and they don't make such a dent in the workday or weekend schedule.
Jumping the Shark Would jazzing things up on the course as per the Great White Shark's suggestions entice Romanin and his fellow pedallers back on a regular basis?
Unlikely, he says.
"These days executives are more conscious of their health and fitness…they gravitate to activities that meet this need," he says.
"It's still missing that edge … I still don't think it's hitting the right spot for what executives are looking for in today's world…For me, it's not about having to wear a polo shirt, it's a time factor."
Not enough hours in the week is a common refrain for time-poor, 30-somethings whose careers are on the rise.
Changing fortunes Whether it's for business or pleasure, it's tough to find a window to don special clothes and drive to a course for a round when the business calendar is bulging and there's a young family at home.
A regular player in his former role as a relationship manager with ANZ Bank, financial services software entrepreneur Bart Jesman, 36, has relegated his clubs to the garage since founding his own firm, FinSuite, five years ago.
Long weeks in the office, a young child at home and a client base that doesn't want to spend half a day trudging round the course with him means they're likely to remain there.
Same here, says Zoom2u's 35-year-old founder Steve Orenstein who prefers snowboarding or floorball, a form of indoor hockey, to eighteen holes.
A sizeable handicap The time factor and stuffy rules combo has helped push golf down in the popularity stakes and even with an image overhaul it's unlikely to see a major resurgence with the under-40s crowd, he believes.
"I have played but I definitely don't think it will continue to be an area where deals are done, on the golf course," Orenstein says.
"There are so many sports out there the younger generation are going after than the game of golf, especially with the dress code and formality.
'There's a place for golf and I do enjoy when I play, the social aspect. What I don't like is the formality, having to wear certain clothing, shorts with socks pulled up …" But while the younger set may be less than enthusiastic, corporate golf days still attract plenty of takers, according to International Speakers Group managing director Rod Loader, who does brisk business supplying retired cricketers to play with executives and their guests.
Not dead yet "Guys that are keen on their golf are still out there and active … it's still an easy sell to get guys to come and play in a golf event," Loader says.
He believes an image upgrade may make the game more accessible to rookie players who are put off by its old school etiquette.
"Especially guys who don't play too often, they can be intimidated walking into the old high-end golf courses and [staff] pulling them up on the way they're dressed," Loader says.
"You don't need people telling your clients they're wearing the wrong socks."
Shortening the game could also increase its appeal, he adds.
"There's merit in shorter games from a time point of view because that does put people off," he says.
Does golf still appeal to you, for leisure or networking? Tell us in the comments section.
